repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - First and Second Municipal Solid
            Waste Sector Development Policy Loans Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First and Second
            Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) Sector Development Policy Loans
            (DPLs) Project for Morocco were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: contributing factors included a long
            history of Bank-client dialogue on sector policies and
            strong analytical foundation, which allowed the Bank to
            accompany the government in a well-designed and phased
            program of homegrown sector reform in a complex sector. The
            programmatic series was centered on a simple policy matrix
            to substantiate the program of reforms as an emerging
            political priority, with shared ownership of the reforms by
            the Ministries of Interior, Finance and Environment.
            Investment lending could not have provided the same leverage
            on reforms, due to the DPL nature as entry point to policy
            dialogue and the visibility accorded to the reform program
            from the engagement of the Bank. The government was fully
            committed to the program and took advantage of the analysis,
            planning framework, implementation support and convening
            power offered by a DPL program whilst maintaining full
            leadership and ownership of the reforms themselves, which
            was also essential factors contributing to the success of
            the DPL program. While private sector participation as
            services providers in the MSW sector increased
            substantially, the capacity building and standard
            specifications supported by the DPL series have shown their
            limit in terms of improving cost effectiveness, and more has
            to be done in terms of market development. For now, the
            major cities have the funds necessary to contract out
            services, based on revenues from the municipal service tax,
            but as coverage rates and service standards continue to
            increase, new sources of funds targeted to MSW should be
            developed, also by looking at investments by the private sector.

Morocco - First and Second Municipal Solid
            Waste Sector Development Policy Loans Project

16494410.majtheme: Urban development,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Institutional development of the municipal
            solid waste sector in Morocco

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            institutional development of municipal solid waste sector in
            Morocco. Out of a total Moroccan population of 30 million,
            18 million lived in urban areas. Moroccan cities are
            characterized by high population densities and rapid growth.
            These cities suffered from several forms of environmental
            degradation, including the effects of poor management of
            Municipal Solid Waste (MSW). In 2008, Morocco produced about
            5 million tons of MSW per year and it is expected to reach
            6.2 million in 2020. The World Bank has been supporting
            Morocco’s efforts to improve economic, environmental, and
            social performance of MSW. The program has supported about
            80 municipalities to improve their collection services and
            upgrade their landfills. Private sector provided cleaning
            and garbage collection services to about 60 percent of the
            urban population compared to about 15 percent before the
            project. An innovative carbon finance program at the
            national level was designed to help local authorities
            mobilize additional financial resources. The program
            improved the reach and quality of solid waste collection
            services and contributed to the effort to mitigate climate
            change effects.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco  - Second Municipal Solid Waste
            Sector Development Policy Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) program is to support the
            Government of Morocco (GoM) in implementing its program of
            reforms aimed at improving the financial, environmental and
            social performance of the municipal solid waste sector in
            Morocco. The first DPL supported the key foundations of the
            Government's reform program, which established the
            enabling environment for an integrated and affordable
            municipal solid waste system. This second DPL supports
            capitalizing on the momentum gained during the first
            operation while deepening the reforms at the regional and
            municipal levels. Support to the municipal solid waste
            reform program is a key component. Second DPL will
            contribute to the achievement of the Country Partnership
            Strategy (CPS') second and third pillars: support to
            the improvement in access to, and quality of services; and
            sustainable development in a changing climate. In addition
            the operation is fully supportive of the CPS cross cutting
            theme of enhancing governance.

Morocco  - Second Municipal Solid Waste

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco  - Second Municipal Solid Waste
            Sector Development Policy Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) program is to support the
            Government of Morocco (GoM) in implementing its program of
            reforms aimed at improving the financial, environmental and
            social performance of the municipal solid waste sector in
            Morocco. The first DPL supported the key foundations of the
            Government's reform program, which established the
            enabling environment for an integrated and affordable
            municipal solid waste system. This second DPL supports
            capitalizing on the momentum gained during the first
            operation while deepening the reforms at the regional and
            municipal levels. Support to the municipal solid waste
            reform program is a key component. Second DPL will
            contribute to the achievement of the Country Partnership
            Strategy (CPS') second and third pillars: support to
            the improvement in access to, and quality of services; and
            sustainable development in a changing climate. In addition
            the operation is fully supportive of the CPS cross cutting
            theme of enhancing governance.
